_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Controlled access (key card) to ammonia machinery rooms

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Costco Wholesale recognizes the companys responsibility in ensuring the safety of the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the Costco Wholesale Meat Plant in Tracy, California.

It is the policy of Costco Wholesale to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the companys goal in minimizing accidental losses, the company has established safety programs that enable facility personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare facility personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

Costco Wholesale draws from several sources and decades of experience + expertise to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  Internal facility personnel with decades of collective experience, the resources of a professional refrigeration contractor, in addition to external risk management consultants all provide guidance to limit the risks of handling ammonia.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the facilitys safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with Cal-OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, CCR Title 8 5189), EPAs Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68), and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program

(CCR Title 19, Division 5, Chapter 2).  The Refrigeration / Maintenance Department has the primary responsibility for implementation of the RMP and PSM policies aimed at reducing the hazards associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.

It is the policy of the Costco Wholesale Tracy Meat Plant to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  If such a release does occur, the facilitys personnel are trained to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility has coordinated emergency response activities with the Tracy Rural Fire Protection District, the South San Joaquin County Fire Authority, as well as the local Hazardous Materials Response team, who provide additional emergency response expertise and support as needed.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Costco Wholesale facility processes ground beef and hot dogs and produces several packaged meat products that are sold in Costco Wholesale retail locations worldwide.  The facility is located at 17880 W. Schulte Road in Tracy, California.  The ammonia refrigeration system was commissioned in 2005 and was built in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Mechanical and Fire Codes.  An expansion in 2010 enabled the plant to manufacture hot dogs that are sold in the retail locations (food courts and stores).

Costco Wholesale Tracy Meat Plants ammonia refrigeration system has a maximum intended inventory of 45,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, that is used in meat processing equipment (including quick freezing), warehouse cold storage, and freezer storage.  The majority of the system is located in two compressor rooms (Main Plant and Hot Dog engine rooms) including the vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the machine room roofs and all of the evaporators and process freezers are located in their respective production / cold storage areas.

The accidental release prevention progr

am starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

Refrigeration process equipment at the plant operates continuously based on operational + temperature demands.  The machinery rooms house the primary equipment including compressors, recirculator packages with pumps, and auxiliary components, while the condensers are located above each machinery room on the facility roof.  The evaporators, freezers, chillers, and other refrigeration process applications are located throughout the facility at / near each refrigerated zone (independently temperature controlled).

Anhydrous Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from product, secondary coolants (glycol), and cold storage rooms to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers (outside), where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor to the atmosphere, causing the ammonia to condense to a liquid, which drains back into the high pressure vessels.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia refrigeration system including:  ammonia leak detection with stack light alarm annunciators, pressure relief system w/ water diffusion tanks, emergency refrigerant control boxes, auto purgers to remove non-condensible gasses, and a refrigeration control system.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the Costco Wholesale facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequenc

es of a significant ammonia release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM and RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, training, management of change + pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permits, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties to ensure upkeep and implementation of each policy within the RMP and PSM programs.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential gaps in compliance and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

Several departments within the facility (Refrigeration, Administration, and Safety) as well as outside resources (Ammonia Refrigeration Contractors, and a Risk Management Consultant) help to ensure the appropriate and ongoing implementation (with recordkeeping) of the various elements of the programs.  PSM Team Meetings include discussions regarding outstanding corrective action items, planned design changes to the ammonia system (if any), changes in personnel, reviewing evacuation drill results, etc.  Any significant issues that are identified are brought to plant leadership to ensure appropriate resources are allocated for timely resolutions.

The ultimate goal for Costco Wholesales PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable the facility to operate the refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern the ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.  In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the l

ocal Fire Departments and Hazardous Materials Response teams.

The ammonia refrigeration system and the associated safety features were designed in accordance with contemporary codes and standards.  The RMP responsible personnel (with guidance from contractors and consultants) also routinely review Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) for the ammonia refrigeration industry to ensure that the facility is properly maintained, and appropriate adjustments / modifications are made based on evolving industry standards.

One of the primary policies within the RMP & PSM programs is the Mechanical Integrity program that details the prescribed inspections / testing / and maintenance tasks that are conducted on all refrigeration system components + auxiliary systems.  The facility utilizes in-house Refrigeration Mechanics for Daily Ammonia System Rounds (w/ log sheet) to monitor system parameters and to alert Management if any conditions are out of range.   Ammonia refrigeration contractors are also assigned the duties for various routine inspections and preventative maintenance tasks + service.

The Costco Wholesale ammonia refrigeration system has many safety design features including ammonia leak detectors, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, emergency stop controls, and Emergency Refrigerant Control Boxes.  In addition, all pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to ensure the integrity of the vessel and associated piping is protected.  Any ammonia that vents from a pressure relief valve is neutralized in the Water Diffusion Tanks.

Much of the safety of the refrigeration system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The facility has Maintenance / Refrigeration personnel on-site 24/7 who monitor for any abnormal conditions.  The Cost

co Wholesale ammonia refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically detail requirements for safety features.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the system are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPAs RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

  --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
  --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (February 2020  February 2025) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds within a 24 hour period, or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as detailed above.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Costco Wholesale facility and is maintained by the Maintenance Department.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220), as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the e

vacuation plan.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what personnel and any other resources that are necessary to remedy the issue.  All employees evacuate to the evacuation assembly areas.  Notifications of response agencies as well the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.  The Costco Wholesale Meat Plant also has an established relationship with the local Fire Department who may be called in to assist depending on the scope of an emergency situation.

The Emergency Plan policy contains procedures detailing how the facility will react to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This policy has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including:  the Tracy Rural Fire Protection District, and South San Joaquin County Fire Authority.

The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

Evacuation drills are also organized and conducted annually by the Safety Department to supplement the training received by all employees at the facility.  As facility management strives to improve safety at the facility, evaluations are documented with suggested improvements, and other observations from the drills.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Costco Wholesale has worked to address safe

ty issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Past studies including:  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, IIAR-9 Gap Assessments, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Costco Wholesale, with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.
  --  Conducting routine RMP / PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by facility personnel, refrigeration contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.
  --  Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facilitys efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
